margot 0.2.1.37

Create a Boxplot with Facets using ggplot2

margot_plot_boxplot.Rd

This function creates a boxplot for one or more variables, faceted by a specified variable (usually time). It offers various customization options for the plot appearance and layout.

Usage

margot_plot_boxplot(
  data,
  y_vars,
  x_var = "wave",
  title = NULL,
  y_label = NULL,
  x_label = NULL,
  data_fraction = 1,
  seed = NULL,
  show_points = FALSE,
  point_alpha = 0.3,
  point_size = 0.5,
  save_path = NULL,
  width = 16,
  height = 8,
  legend_position = "bottom",
  y_limits = NULL,
  facet_type = "grid",
  facet_scales = "free_x",
  facet_space = "free_x",
  facet_ncol = NULL,
  facet_nrow = NULL,
  ...
)

Arguments

data

A data frame containing the variables to be plotted.

y_vars

A list of variable names to be plotted on the y-axis.

x_var

The name of the variable to be used for faceting (default is "wave").

title

The title of the plot (optional).

y_label

The label for the y-axis (optional).

x_label

The label for the x-axis (optional, not typically used due to faceting).

data_fraction

The fraction of data to use (default is 1, i.e., all data).

seed

A seed for random sampling if data_fraction < 1 (optional).

show_points

Logical, whether to show individual data points (default is FALSE).

point_alpha

Alpha value for data points if shown (default is 0.3).

point_size

Size of data points if shown (default is 0.5).

save_path

Path to save the plot (optional).

width

Width of the saved plot in inches (default is 16).

height

Height of the saved plot in inches (default is 8).

legend_position

Position of the legend (default is "bottom").

y_limits

Y-axis limits (optional).

facet_type

Type of faceting: "grid" or "wrap" (default is "grid").

facet_scales

Scales for facet panels (default is "free_x").

facet_space

Space for facet panels (default is "free_x").

facet_ncol

Number of columns for facet_wrap (optional).

facet_nrow

Number of rows for facet_wrap (optional).

...

Additional arguments passed to geom_boxplot().

Value

A ggplot object representing the boxplot.

Examples

# Example 1: Basic usage with two variables
boxplot_basic <- margot_plot_boxplot(
  data = your_data,
  y_vars = list("variable1", "variable2"),
  x_var = "wave",
  title = "My Boxplot"
)
#> 
#> ── Margot Plot Boxplot ─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
#> ℹ Preparing data...
#> ✖ An error occurred: object 'your_data' not found
#> <simpleError in eval(expr, envir, enclos): object 'your_data' not found>

# Example 2: Using facet wrap with a single row
boxplot_wrap_single_row <- margot_plot_boxplot(
  data = your_data,
  y_vars = list("warm_muslims", "warm_immigrants"),
  x_var = "wave",
  title = "Warmth Towards Muslims and Immigrants",
  y_label = "Warmth",
  facet_type = "wrap",
  facet_nrow = 1,
  width = 20,
  height = 6,
  save_path = here::here("path", "to", "save")
)
#> 
#> ── Margot Plot Boxplot ─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
#> ℹ Preparing data...
#> ✖ An error occurred: object 'your_data' not found
#> <simpleError in eval(expr, envir, enclos): object 'your_data' not found>

# Example 3: Showing individual data points
boxplot_with_points <- margot_plot_boxplot(
  data = your_data,
  y_vars = list("variable1", "variable2", "variable3"),
  x_var = "wave",
  title = "Boxplot with Data Points",
  show_points = TRUE,
  point_alpha = 0.2,
  point_size = 0.3
)
#> 
#> ── Margot Plot Boxplot ─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
#> ℹ Preparing data...
#> ✖ An error occurred: object 'your_data' not found
#> <simpleError in eval(expr, envir, enclos): object 'your_data' not found>
